answers.author: Bill Atkinson
answers.text:
Looking back 20 years ago, I would recommend two things to new managers that I learned very quickly.  First, slow down and take a deep breath.  You are not going to change the world merely with your presence.  Second, listen, listen, listen to those around you.  Don't come into the situation like a bull in a china closet thinking that you are the only one with answers.  
If you do this, you are destined to isolate yourself and you cannot do it alone.  If you do employ listening skills, humility and sound decision making, you will be sought out as a leader.

answers.author: Jacob Foos
answers.text:
From my experience the most common and damaging mistakes come from a lack of communication.  This applies to all levels within the organization, not just the corner office.

answers.author: Sam Anselm
answers.text:
Great question. I'm still the interim (first time gig), but so far I think Jacob has hit the nail on the head, and I think Bill's answer is similar. From my experience thus far, I'd also throw this out there - don't assume your council/board knows everything that's happening, so don't surprise them with anything. Again, open communication is key.
